message: Thanks for the quick answer.
Oh, that was my next question :-)
location.hash i think does it?
I remember looking for the same thing awhile back before learning it wasn't passed along
I'm building an Ajax enabled app and want to use hashtags for deep linking. However, the standard request object in Django seems to ignore them.
One common practice is for example to use pseudo-paths like "#foo/bar/" in your hashtags and translate that into real URL paths when making the AJAX request.
Correct. This is because a browser never sends the location hash to the server. You need to handle this with JavaScript client-side.
Yes, it seems that big sites like the new Twitter and some latest Google sites (new groups) are using a #! as a marker for that.
I see. So I need to take the hash and include it somehow in the XHR?
Depends on what you're trying to do. But that would be one way, yes.
You could also use a client-side js framework to map fragments to routes, like http://sammyjs.org/ or http://documentcloud.github.com/backbone/#Controller
and I'd avoid hashbang urls if you're looking to do the site "proper", use the HTML5 history api instead, and just serve degraded webpages to those using lesser browsers
I'd personally recommend backbone, but people tell me sammy and it do play nice together regardless

I actually use backbone in a few "web applications" that are mostly static pages on top of an API. I think making the site proper is less necessary then, especially when the application is not public.

The "#!" version isn't just to look cool; it's a "standard" proposed by Google to make hash-URLs indexable in search engines. It's an ugly hack and only supported by Google, AFAIK. http://code.google.com/web/ajaxcrawling/docs/getting-started.html
@carljm I remember when I used alta vista for image searches because google's image search was bad

Some articles worth reading on the practice: http://www.isolani.co.uk/blog/javascript/BreakingTheWebWithHashBangs http://blog.benward.me/post/3231388630 http://www.tbray.org/ongoing/When/201x/2011/02/09/Hash-Blecch
